Award.AbstractNarration:
This project funds the National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance (VentureWell) to support their involvement in NSF's Innovation Corps (I-Corps). VentureWell has responsibility to: recruit and train I-Corps core instructors, adjuncts, teaching assistants, and I-Corps observation deputies for workshops planned in six cities throughout the country; prepare and curate canonical I-Corps curricula; extract best-practices; prepare, disseminate, and update a Faculty Teaching Guide and Faculty Training Workbook; and, manage evaluations of I-Corps Team experiences.

The NSF I-Corps programs were devised to address the challenges that the United States faces in rapidly and efficiently bringing emerging science and engineering innovations to use in industry and commerce. To maintain world leadership in scientific and engineering research and education, the USA needs processes that enable the practical and scalable application of promising discoveries from research and university laboratories. For university research to achieve greater impact, academic researchers and their students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) need tools and preparation for evaluating whether research discoveries can be readily translated into practical applications and eventual commercialization. NSF established the I-Corps programs beginning in 2011 to support NSF-funded researchers in learning how to evaluate their scientific research for commercial potential. With this project, VentureWell contributes directly to the I-Corps programs. In particular, the I-Corps programs provide NSF-funded principal investigators and their team members with funding and training enabling them to evaluate their technologies and research discoveries for commercial feasibility. The ultimate goal is to increase the economic and societal impact of NSF research funding directly, through commercialization of research, and indirectly, by equipping scientists and engineers with skills and experience in developing and testing economically scalable models for the development of a product or technology. I-Corps grantees are expected to reach a decision about the commercial readiness of their technology or product and take with them a set of skills that they can continue to apply in their careers. I-Corps participants evaluate and translate their research into applications that have commercial potential and can benefit society. Many participants will have identified promising commercial pathways that can lead to new high tech ventures or licensing opportunities. Since the program's inception, I-Corps teams have formed almost 400 companies. These companies operate in a broad range of sectors including health, energy, materials, agriculture and information technology and are geographically distributed across the United States.

VentureWell is uniquely qualified to engage the I-Corps community having been catalyzing the creation of scalable science and technology ventures for more than 21 years through processes of funding, teaching, mentoring, and advising. VentureWell's mission is to increase opportunities for technological innovation and entrepreneurship, support the development science and technology-based enterprises, and facilitate access to early sources of capital so that faculty researchers and their students can take their innovative ideas to scale. Since its inception, VentureWell has trained over 1,700 early-stage innovation teams and helped launch over 788 ventures that have raised almost $900 million in public and private investment.

Institution.Name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NATIONAL COLLEGIATE INVENTORS & INNOVATORS ALLIANCE, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance

POR.DRECONTENT:
I think I-Corps was one of the hardest things that I have ever had the privilege of doing, and I am extremely grateful to have been a part of this experience. It was an invaluable learning experience and one that I will continue to benefit from in the future.

-- I-CorpsTM Entrepreneurial Lead

NSF Innovation Corps (I-CorpsTM) program supports university researchers with promising innovations to extend their focus beyond the laboratory and move towards commercialization, in turn accelerating the economic and societal benefits of their NSF-funded research projects. Established in 2011, this process has proven an effective method of learning and discovery to assess the commercial potential of scientific discoveries, which then leads to the creation of new ventures and strong economic development. VentureWell has worked with NSF as a key partner in the implementation and evaluation of the I-CorpsTM program, which has trained more than 4,400 innovators to date, and in the growth of the national innovation ecosystem since 2012.

Through this project (award IIP-1741434), VentureWell supported the implementation and evaluation of seven national team trainings (for 114 teams), implemented a faculty training, provided the materials to course participants, and curated best practices for pedagogical improvements. Additional outcomes of this project include defining and implementing the new Deputy Faculty position to document best practices and pedagogical nuances of the I-CorpsTM faculty as they deliver the curriculum, reaching a new milestone this year of 50 cohorts trained, and piloting a new structure for mentor-mentee partnerships.

The work performed under this grant uses a refined and consistently delivered curriculum for the exclusive purpose of teaching STEM students and faculty how to commercialize their discoveries and evaluate the potential of their research for practical, economically scalable applications. Participants report that the I-CorpsTM program has led them to think and do research differently, namely to be more sophisticated in determining the applications of their discoveries, seeking practical applications, conceptualizing startup opportunities, and having language and processes that enable them to successfully engage with industry and research partners. The program may also increase an entrepreneurial mindset among participating post-doctoral students, graduate students, and undergraduate students.

The economic benefits of the I-CorpsTM program are clear. To date, the national course has led to the creation of 679 known startups that have raised a total of approximately $335M in follow-on funding (as of October 2018). Almost 1,000 jobs have been created in science and technology through I-CorpsTM companies. This process, once learned, becomes a tool that scientific and technical researchers can apply continually and teach others, maximizing the impact of their ideas on the world and the economy.

In Spring 2018, the I-CorpsTM program launched a pilot study to determine the extent to which assigning a mentor to teams, as opposed to the traditional method of teams selecting their own mentor, affected a team's experience in the course. Of particular interest was whether there were significant differences in the expectations that teams had for their mentors as well as the frequency, satisfaction, quality, and substance of the interaction between teams and mentors. For the pilot, teams in the cohort taught by the Midwest Node were assigned a mentor by NSF and those mentors each supported two teams. Teams in the cohorts taught by the Bay Area, Los Angeles, and Southwest Nodes selected their own mentors, each of whom supported one team only. Assigned mentors received a $7,000 stipend in addition to travel expenses; self-selected mentors were volunteers.

Exploratory analyses of data from the pilot study indicate that core team members (namely the Principal Investigator, also known as the Technical Lead, and Entrepreneurial Lead) and their mentors were generally aligned on their expectations of the role of the mentor regardless of whether the mentor was assigned or self-selected. Even though assigned mentors spent less time with their teams per week than self-selected mentors and provided less assistance with the core I-CorpsTM activity of customer interviews, there was no significant difference between the assigned and self-selected mentor teams' generally high ratings of the quality and satisfaction with the mentor-mentee relationship. The results should be considered preliminary due to limited scale of the study, however, these data provide no strong evidence that there is a significant and consistent difference between the experience and assessment of core teams with assigned paid mentors and those who self-select their volunteer mentor.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2018
Modified by: Philip J Weilerstein
